article_title: Fast-growing Medi-Cal has shortage of doctors
article_text:
Fast-growing Medi-Cal has shortage of doctors

Photo: Paul Chinn, The Chronicle Rozena Abriha is seen at her home in San Jose, Calif. on Thursday,...

Rozena Abriha enrolled in Medi-Cal earlier this year and was grateful to receive health coverage. But, despite making about a dozen phone calls, she hasn’t been able to find a doctor willing to take new patients. So Abriha has sought treatment at an urgent care center multiple times in the past few months for cold sores and bacterial infections that wouldn’t go away.

article_metadata.sailthru.author: By Anna Gorman
article_metadata.description: [...] despite making about a dozen phone calls, she hasn’t been able to find a doctor willing to take new patients.  In an effort to control costs, California has relied heavily on managed care insurance companies to treat patients like Abriha.  The state pays insurers a fixed amount per patient and expects the companies to provide access to doctors and comprehensive care, rather than paying for each medical visit or procedure under a fee-for-service model.  The California audit found the state didn’t verify that insurers’ directories of doctors were accurate, or that the plans had enough doctors to meet patients’ medical needs.  [...] thousands of phone calls to an ombudsman’s office — created to investigate complaints — went unanswered every month.  Advocates and experts say the state has moved too quickly to shift people into managed care plans and given too much unsupervised responsibility to the companies  The sheer number of patients — along with their complex health needs — means the state needs to do a better job tracking the plans responsible for caring for them, said Gerald Kominski, director of the UCLA Center for Health Policy Research.  New proposed federal regulations designed to improve Medicaid managed care could help California’s Medi-Cal patients by requiring states to ensure that patients have enough access to doctors and hospitals, limiting profit margins and establishing a system for rating the quality of plans.  California Department of Health Care Services officials said they already have made some changes and are monitoring doctor networks more thoroughly than the audit found.  Many newer beneficiaries, including seniors and people with disabilities, have multiple chronic illnesses.  Each transition has been rocky, with patients and advocates raising concerns about patients’ inability to find primary care doctors or specialists.  Some of the issues have arisen because Medi-Cal grew much faster and bigger than anybody predicted, said Stan Rosenstein, a consultant and former chief deputy director at the state Health Care Services Department.  [...] he said caring for people through managed care is a vast improvement over the old fee-for-service system, where doctors got paid per visit.
